question: 5 (b)
statement_html:
Consider an internet with six sites. The stochastic matrix describing the behaviour of a web surfer (with damping factor zero) is

\[\begin{aligned} P = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ \frac12 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 \\ \frac12 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \\ 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 1 & 0 & \frac12 \\ 0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

(b) If we begin with equal probabilities of being at each site, what are the probabilities of being at each site after one step? What is the probability of being at site 6 after two steps?
statement_latex:
Consider an internet with six sites. The stochastic matrix describing
the behaviour of a web surfer (with damping factor zero) is

\begin{align*}
P = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
\frac12 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 \\
\frac12 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \\
0 & \frac13 & 0 & 1 & 0 & \frac12 \\
0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & \frac12 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

\textbf{(b)} If we begin with equal probabilities of being at each site,
what are the probabilities of being at each site after one step? What is
the probability of being at site 6 after two steps?
statement_raw:
Consider an internet with six sites. The stochastic matrix describing the behaviour of a web surfer (with damping factor zero) is

:<math>
P = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
\frac12 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 \\
\frac12 & \frac13 & 0 & 0 & \frac12 & 0 \\
0 & \frac13 & 0 & 1 & 0 & \frac12 \\
0 & 0 & \frac13 & 0 & \frac12 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

'''(b)''' If we begin with equal probabilities of being at each site, what are the probabilities of being at each site after one step? What is the probability of being at site 6 after two steps?
